content.webTitle: No birthday cake for Amir Khan with Floyd Mayweather dream in sight

fields.headline: No birthday cake for Amir Khan with Floyd Mayweather dream in sight
fields.bodyText: Amir Khan turned 28 on Monday yet there were no Sin City celebrations. The two-times world champion was certainly delighted by a very comfortable-looking pair of slippers his father, Shah, had given him. For the record, they looked lovely. Yet there was no cake. No party. No birthday bash with his friends. Three years ago Khan was sucked into all that and the result was a defeat, albeit a controversial one, by Lamont Peterson which meant his WBF and IBF titles were ripped from his grasp. Now though, as the boy from Bolton sat in a plush Las Vegas hotel dissecting his preparation and mental state before a critical fight with the American Devon Alexander here on Saturday, it was clear there has been a lot of growing up since those naive, perhaps more carefree days. With the trainer Virgil Hunter now calling the shots, a fight against Floyd Mayweather lurching into view and a young family to support, Khan says he has changed. A career-defining, and bank balance-boosting, showdown with Mayweather is the dream. Khan makes no bones about wanting his cake. He will eat it – just not now. Alexander, who should not be underestimated, needs to be dealt with first. “I really like the slippers but I’d rather not have presents because you may lose focus,” he said. “I don’t want to be happy and enjoying things. I can save all that till after the fight. “I am a fighter; I am going to war. My life is on the line so I can’t enjoy myself eating cake. I have a big fight ahead of me. Once you’re in camp Virgil says the whole focus has to be about the fight. “Before that Peterson fight I had all my mates around, we were eating cake and talking about what was going on in Bolton. I lost my focus. That wouldn’t happen now. I perform better when I am bored. “I feel much better now than when I was 26. I feel stronger, healthier and fitter than I did at 26. I’m in better shape, I’m a better weight. I’ve changed a lot in my life because it’s not easy to get as fit or strong at my age. “I can see myself getting better as a fighter. I am becoming more strict, professional and more disciplined at this age. “That’s why I think I am getting to my peak. I thought I might have hit my peak at 24, 25 but I’m getting to my peak now. Physically I have changed a lot. Being married with a settled life helps me tremendously.” Khan arrived from his San Francisco training base late on Monday evening and as his entourage made their way towards the forever glowing Las Vegas strip he would have seen the huge billboards promoting his first fight at the MGM Grand, a place where boxing dreams are made and shattered in equal measure. On the undisputed glitziest stage of all Khan will be wearing the most expensive shorts ever. Apparently they will have a 24-carat gold thread on the waistband and are made of white nappa leather. Fashonistas may wince yet this is Khan’s attempt at showing the boxing world he needs to be taken very seriously. He knows coming to America and succeeding catapults careers like nothing else. Providing for his wife and baby daughter has become as important as anything else, though. Khan is smart enough to know he will not be in the fight game forever. “Being a father has changed me a lot. Everything I do in sport now is to give my family a comfortable life, I want my daughter Lamaisah to grow up and say: ‘My dad was a great champion.’ That’s the biggest motivation to have when your little girl goes to school and her friends say: ‘Your dad was a great fighter.’ “I want to win this fight and I want to go on to bigger fights in the future. I’m doing it for my family. I’m a family man now. I am putting my body on the line. I am going to war. “It’s not just about me, or feeding Amir. It’s about my whole family, looking after them. It’s only given me strength in training camp. Knowing I have a little girl helps me get through tough times and tough training camps. “This has been the hardest training camp I’ve ever had. I’ve done around 160 rounds of sparring; we’ve just been very focused. Being away from her is hard – being away from my little girl – but it’s just one of those things. I last saw her seven weeks ago when they came to training camp. “I’m not putting on any nappies though! I put the boxing gloves on and say: ‘I can’t change nappies!’ “Having a family is a motivation. It is driving me and pushing me to try harder. Everything I’m doing is for them. When you are on your own, that hunger may not be there. “I’m not really a big spender or one of those guys who splashes money on things, like Mayweather. He needs to earn big to go with his lifestyle. I don’t need to make billions in my career. I just want to make sure I have enough and I’ve made enough for her education.” Smart words indeed. Khan appears to be learning at just the right time.
